trial_identification.studytitle: Patient Retention in HIV Medical Care in a Primary Care Practice in Australia
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Patient Retention in HIV Medical Care in a Primary Care Practice in Australia

interventions.interventions:
Retained in Care - Each patient who had at least 2 practice visits separated by =90 days in a year involving HIV laboratory monitoring until 31st of March 2014.
Lost to follow-up (LTFU) - Each patient who had at 2 practice visits separated by =90 days in a year involving HIV laboratory monitoring but did not maintain regular attendance at HHMP until 31st March, 2014.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The primary outcome measures are the rates of current linkage and retention in care for HIV-infected adults at Holdsworth House Medical Practice (HHMP) over a 5-year period

secondaryOutcome.outcome: A secondary outcome measure is to determine the factors associated with loss to follow up (LTFU) in the study population over a 5-year period

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
- Documented HIV-1 infection
- Attendance during the study period for at least 2 visits >3 months and <12 months apart with measured laboratory virological or immunological markers (either on-site or at a co-management site)
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- Attendance by patient with HIV infection who does not have laboratory markers of HIV viral load or CD4 count measured
- Incomplete/inaccessible patient records to enable patient to meet inclusion criteria
- Initial visit after 1st January 2014

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The purpose of this study is to determine linkage and retention in care in patients with HIV infection and reasons for loss to follow up Care in a High HIV-caseload Inner City Primary Care Practice in Sydney, Australia.
The investigators hypothesise that patients attending HHMP will have higher rates of linkage and retention in care than the US HIV-infected population, and equivalent to Australian modelling.
